Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Continuation of the XENON Dark Matter Search at LNGS
Award.AbstractNarration:
Multiple astronomical observations have established that about 85% of the matter in the universe is not made of known particles. Deciphering the nature of this so-called Dark Matter is of fundamental importance to cosmology, astrophysics, and high-energy particle physics with profound implications for our view of the Universe. A leading hypothesis is that it is comprised of Weakly Interacting Massive Particles, or WIMPs, that were produced moments after the Big Bang. If WIMPs are the dark matter, then their presence in our galaxy may be detectable via scattering from atomic nuclei in detectors located deep underground to help reject backgrounds due to cosmic rays.

The identification of Dark Matter (DM) poses a challenge that is being addressed with a variety of complementary approaches and technologies. The direct search for DM with the XENON project at the Gran Sasso laboratory promises an extremely cost-efficient approach to cover vast regions of expected DM parameter space. This award will enable the US groups in XENON to participate in the operations and data analysis of XENON100 well into 2015 when the start of the scientific program with XENON1T is expected. With a strong presence at Gran Sasso, the US groups will maintain a leading role in the commissioning and operation of XENON1T.

Broader Impacts:
A number of students as well as post-doctoral researchers are involved in the XENON project at universities across the US. They are exposed to a variety of subjects in fundamental physics and cosmology, and trained in the development and application of state-of-the-art technologies, preparing them to become future leaders in the field. The instrumentation and techniques used in XENON are relevant to a wide range of applications, from areas in homeland security and medical imaging, to the analysis and statistical treatment of large data sets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most of the matter in the Universe is actually not in the form of known atoms that we can touch and see around us, but is composed of some new, unknown kind of matter. The nature of this so-called dark matter is one of the greatest outstanding questions of contemporary physics, being frantically searched for with experiments at the Large Hadron Collider, in space, and on Earth. As we fly with the Solar System through our Milky Way galaxy, we constantly plow through a halo of this dark matter. Thus, there is a constant head-wind of dark matter particles that penetrate everything and everybody on Earth. We do not feel them since their chance of interaction is very small, similarly to the better known particles such as neutrinos and cosmic rays. One way to attempt to unravel what dark matter is made of is then to try to detect some of these particles as they pass through a detector.

Led by the Columbia University PI, and with continuing support from the National Science Foundation, the XENON collaboration has constructed, operated, and analysed the XENON1T detector, which is at present the most sensitive apparatus looking for dark matter. In developing this unique type of detector to search for a rare WIMP signal, many challenges had to be overcome; first and foremost the reduction of the overwhelmingly large background from many sources, from radioactivity to cosmic rays. XENON1T uses ultra-pure liquid xenon in a cryostat made from carefully selected materials to reduce the radioactive background from known particles. It is located about a mile deep underground in the Laboratori Nazionali del Gran Sasso in central Italy to shield it from cosmic rays, and further within a large water tank for additional shielding against ambient radiation as well. The liquid xenon is instrumented with highly sensitive, single-photon sensors in a so-called time projection chamber (TPC) so that each particle interaction can be pictured in three dimensions. This helps to further reduce radioactive backgrounds, which are mostly located near the materials, from dark matter interactions that are expected to occur uniformly throughout the xenon volume. Today, XENON1T is the largest dark matter experiment with the lowest background ever measured, counting a mere 630 events in one year and one tonne of xenon.

XENON1T is the third generation of a series of detectors leading the search, starting from the XENON10 result in 2008, to XENON100 in 2012, to today with XENON1T being the world's first tonne-scale liquid xenon detector. After a one-year search, XENON1T has found no evidence for the presence of dark matter. The search results, published in Physical Review Letters, are based on 1300 kg out of the total 2000 kg active xenon target and 279 days of data, making it the first WIMP search with a noble liquid target exposure of 1.0 tonne x year. Only two background events were expected in the innermost, cleanest region of the detector, but none were detected, setting the most stringent constraints on WIMP interactions to date. To continue the search for this elusive dark matter, the collaboration is now preparing an upgrade of XENON1T, called XENONnT, with a total of 8000 kg of Xe in a new detector.

To be able to realize such an increase in size, several new technical challenges must be overcome. With support from NSF, several R&D facilities were developed by the Columbia group, including the XENON1T Demonstrator Facility which was used to develop the cryogenic system of XENON1T and which has now been modified to develop and test purification of Xe in liquid phase for XENONnT.   Fast and continuous purification of the entire liquid xenon volume is necessary to remove impuritues continuously introduce by materials outgassing  which in turn degrade the detectable signal.

While preparations are being made for XENONnT, XENON1T continues to acquire high quality data for the dark matter search, and demonstration of new calibration and background reduction techniques. With another factor of four increase in fiducial target mass, and ten times less background rate, XENONnT will be ready in 2019 for a new exploration of particle Dark Matter at a level of sensitivity nobody imagined when the project started in 2002.
